Reviews.Title: Amazing LCD: Picture Quality, Semi-Matte Screen
Reviews.Author: Average Joe
Reviews.Content: Background:After doing extensive research across the board, I ended up deciding I would probably like the Samsung A650 series. I went into BB to try and take a look for myself, the Full Gloss screen threw reflections all over the place, and bothered me quite a bit.Now take the guts of the A650 and put it into the same package, with a semi-matte screen. Now you have a killer combination that looks amazing on the eyes.Don't take my word for it, More Reviews:-Consumer Reports loves Samsung LCD's, which are ranked #1-Go to [...] , check out the Forums->LCD, you can waste your life on this site, I'd say go for the Pro reviews of the A650, and you'll see why people love this TV-Check out the reviews for the A650's here on amazon, http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B001413D94/-Cnet's review of the A650, you will notice the only drawbacks they listed were "relatively expensive" amazon helps here, and "shiny screen reflects ambient room lighting" and the A630's semi-matte screen works to solve that issue, [...]Recommendation:I'm very happy with the TV: the back light is even across the TV, the blacks are crisp, picture quality can't be beat, the 120hz+auto motion result in smooth images and the semi-matte screen doesn't act like a mirror for the room like the A650's do. Finally, the surrounding frame is leaner and not nearly as noticeable as the A650s.Highly recommended. 5 Stars.

Reviews.Title: 630 or 650 or 550?
Reviews.Author: Comdet
Reviews.Content: After reading reviews in Cnet and Consumer Reports, and feedback from owners on the AVS board, I knew I wanted to get a Samsung LCD. But which one? The 550, 630 and 650 are all highly rated, and all fell within my price range.I first looked at the 550. Great TV and the lowest price. The picture quality was top-notch, but it did not have the 120hz technology and Samsung's smoothing system (called AMP) to reduce motion judder. In side-by-side viewing, I could see a difference in the picture with those features, and, since the price difference was not much, decided to move up to the 6-series.Keep in mind that 120hz and AMP are two different things. You can turn AMP off (or set it to low, medium or high); you can't turn off 120hz unless you are in game mode. I like AMP set at low -- to my eye, that improves the picture without making it too smooth and video-like.Both the 650 and 630 are fantastic TVs, and either one would be a great choice. The major difference between the two is the glassiness of the screen - the 650 has a high gloss screen; the 630 has a matte screen (basically the same as the 550, but with a tiny bit more gloss). I have a very bright living room with lots of windows. The 650 acted like a mirror, reflecting everything to the point of being seriously distracting -- you can see yourself in the screen in dark scenes. The 630 was the perfect compromise -- better quality picture than the 550, but far less gloss than the 650.The advantage of the glossy screen is that it give more "pop" and saturation to the picture. Colors are deeper, blacks are richer, and the overall picture quality is a bit better. If I was using the TV in a darker environment (such as a basement), I'd go for the 650. But given the brightness of the room, the 630 was (for me) the better choice.I've been told the sound quality in the 6-series is a bit better than the 5-series. That was not an issue for me since I turn off the TV speakers and run the sound through a receiver. If you plan on using the TV speakers you may want to listen to both sets to see if you hear a difference.Very pleased with the set so far. You need to do a bit of tweaking to get the picture perfect, but the menus make it easy to do so. You can find configuration setups on several boards that will help point you in the right direction.Other pluses of the 630 are the more muted Touch of Red in the bezel. I'm not a big fan of the red color, so having it less visible is a plus. Very nice remote with easy to find buttons.I'm using the set with a Denon 1909 receiver, an Oppo 983H DVD player, and KEF 3000 series speakers. Everything works great together and I'm continually wowed by how great it looks and sounds.

Reviews.Title: This is the 46 inch you want, at the best price
Reviews.Author: Scott Roberts
Reviews.Content: I have been watching LCD prices for 2 years.  40 inch LCDs have been dropping $50 per month for the last 6 months and it seems to have reached a plateau and may drop only $25 a month for the next 6 months. 46 inch has been dropping $100 per month the past 6 months and will drop $50 to $70 per month for the next 6 months.  With the recession, they may still drop $100 per month.I just bought this one, but i recommend waiting 6 more months if 46 inch is "your size" because losing $50 to $70 per month is a lot just to have a bigger TV.  Samsung and Sony are the best LCDs and this is (was?) the best price on a 46 inch Samsung and is as good as any other 46 inch LCD Samsung makes, but $800 less.  The "better" 46 inch Samsungs are thinner, a little better contrast ("brighter"), about 8% less weight, and have something called "infolink" that brings in active content like sports scores and stock prices.  The 60% increase in price for the other 46 inch Samsungs is too much difference for too little improvement.  They will come down in price $100 per month until getting to this price. This 630 model is a smaller number than the 850 or 950, but the 630 is only 2 months old.This 630 model is a "matte" screen.  It's for our den where there is a lot of light everywhere, so i prefer the 630 matte. The 650 is a "glossy" screen which means it can be more of stunning contrast and sharpness, but with possibly more reflection off the screen.This at $1370 is the lowest price on the internet right now, 10/6/2008 with free shipping and no tax.  Circuit city is selling it for $1700 plus tax.  Some are saying that the economic downturn is causing prices to drop faster than expected.  I expect this model to be $1000 in less than 6 months.  February might be the time to get a 46 inch LCD if that's the size and type of TV you've been waiting for.I have turned off the Auto-Motion Plus 120 Hz feature because it makes it look like I'm watching a 50 Hz BBC program.  I have "fast" eyes and i can see the flicker when there is movement due to the greater sharpness that Auto-Motion Plus gives.  There's something fishy about the "120 Hz" spec because the flicker feels about like 70 to 80 Hz on an old computer CRT.  I suspect that with AMP "on" it's not really 120 Hz in order to give it better sharpness.  So with 120 Hz turned off, there is just a little more blur on movement, but at least it doesn't feel like I'm watching an old episode of Dr Who.  In hindsight, i would have bought one of the older models that doesn't have the Auto-Motion Plus 120 Hz just to save a few bucks even if there was less contrast.  Samsung is really pushing this new feature, but I prefer it off. Others prefer it set to "low".The blur during movement on these new Samsungs (with or without the Auto-Motion Plus 120 Hz) is much better than the old LCDs, but it still is not as good as a CRT, plasma, or rear-projection.The contrast ("birghtness") on this is way way more than we need.  The brightness needs increasing during daytime because we have a lot of sunlight coming in, and then decreased again at night.A 46 inch LCD uses 250 Watt verses 500 W for a plasma.  This is the reason I choose LCD over plasma.  A 500 watt plasma "heater" in the room is good for winter, but not cool for summer.  500 W costs 5 cents per hour for electricity.Now that we're not even using it on a wall, I wonder if i should have got a rear-projection.I recently saw a $1400 LCD 46 inch Sony at a target (new edit 10/12/2008).  I was surprised to see Sony at a competitive price.  These prices are still dropping fast.=== UPDATE ===I am a little less happy with LCD technology. In comparing the LCD to my CRT and home theatre, the LCD easily wins on sharpness and contrast (at least over the projector).  But still there is something "sharper" about CRT and projection over LCD, and I prefer them over this LCD. What I have found out is this: the pixels in an LCD may be flashing at least as fast, but they do not have a "dark period" between frames so that our eyes see more blur even though in reality the screen is not blurring more.  Apparently, our eyes really need the dark time between frames to eliminate the perception of a blur.  Phillips ClearLCD fixes this and samsung and others are working on it.  Here's more info on this:[...]

Reviews.Title: LN46A630 - Quit Researching and Just Buy It!
Reviews.Author: MRA
Reviews.Content: I have owned my LN46A630 for two weeks now and could not be happier, in fact I am watching it right now.  Set-up was a breeze.  I am not an audio/videophile and just wanted a good tv.  I considered the 550, the 630 and the 650 series.  I went with the 630 largely based on looks.  I have several windows to the left of my tv and have had no glare problems whatsoever.  Also, the frame has a much smaller profile and you get the added benefit of the 120hz. The Touch of Color seems much more muted compared to the 650 and I like that. I don't have bluray hooked up to it yet so I can't comment on how that looks.Save yourself the hassle of having to buy HDMI cables by ordering them when you buy the tv.  I bought a mid-priced cable set and have been pleased with the picture.  I refuse to cough up $120 for a Monster HDMI cable.I sit about 10' from the tv and the picture size is just right.  However, I would recommend stepping up to the 52" if you were any farther than this.The tv has varied by $20 on Amazon since I bought it. Since it is a new model you probably won't see any major price decreases for some time.  Just but the darn thing and enjoy it, you won't be disappointed.

Reviews.Title: great TV; but it had to be repaired after 2 days
Reviews.Author: William T. Reach
Reviews.Content: Original post:The TV worked great for 2 days--the picture, features, functionality were just what I hoped for. But then after 2 days it turned itself off and went into an infinite loop of turning itself off and on again. I have a service request in to Samsung and will update this post when the issue is resolved. It seemed important to point out potential manufacturing problems with these very popular units.Update:I put in a repair request using Samsung's online system. Got a call back the next day and scheduled visit from a Samsung repairman (actual Samsung van showed up, so not a third party company). He opened it up and found which board was at fault. He had guessed the power supply board and had a replacement, but it was something else. So he had to leave, get the new part shipped over, and rescheduled 4 days later. He just finished the repair, and the TV seems to be working fine.If I can find how to upgrade my rating, I will, because the TV itself is great. Works smoothly with my Tivo (via HDMI) and blu-ray DVD (via HDMI; both tivo and blu-ray send sound over to my stereo by optical digital audio).The matte finish on the screen really does help against reflection: I no longer see a reflection of the lamps in my living room as I used to on my old TV. So if you are making the plasma (or any reflective coating) versus LCD decision, this particular unit does have a nice diffusive coating.The "touch of red" on the plastic border around the LCD panel is very subtle, and I don't think my family even noticed---they never said anything. I personally like it, but usually you can't tell (or wouldn't notice) that it is not black.

Reviews.Title: Exactly what I've been looking for!
Reviews.Author: Balto Reader "bils"
Reviews.Content: I had waited until now to make the switch to HDTV, obsessing for nearly 2 years about plasma vs LCD vs DLP, size (40/42"? 46"? 50/52"?), and finding the right price-to-quality point.  After focusing for a couple weeks on the LN46A630, I finally made the purchase. I'm 100% satisfied.It has a stunning HD picture. Zero glare/reflection. Lots of settings, accessible from a fairly straight-forward menu. Just the right size for a viewing distance of 8 feet. And definitely the right price compared to others I was considering.The first thing I watched on it was "Planet Earth" on blu-ray (I got a Sony BD player at the same time). Incredible!!!I couldn't be happier with my purchase.

Reviews.Title: great tv
Reviews.Author: H. Gross
Reviews.Content: Chose this TV over the samsung LN46A650 because of the semi-matte finish and because it has less red around edge.  The semi-matte is great, only see any reflection in extremely direct light.  The red "Touch of Color" is almost non-existant on this model, you really have to get close to see that there's any red at all.  Picture is amazing with HD, bluray, PS3, and even SD channels are better than I expected.  Swiveling pedestal also a nice touch, makes it easy for me to get behind it and swap out connectors (HDMI, component, etc all work great).  If I had one negative about the TV it would be that I have yet to find programming (HD or otherwise) that really benefits from the Auto Motion Plus 120hz feature.  After a few minutes I turned it off, tried using it (low, medium, high, auto) again randomly with bluray, videogames and sports, but always end up turning it off again.  It just can't seem to interpolate the frames to maintain consistent onscreen motion and is EXTREMELY annoying.  It DOES do better with Bluray, but I still don't see any way that I would keep it turned on.Still, this TV is incredible and deserves five stars (I didn't buy it because of the 120hz feature).  Also, I recommend you buy cheap HDMI cable.  I bought a couple $5 HDMI's online and there's no discernible difference between them and more expensive ones.

Reviews.Title: Good TV, but some issues, unfortunately...
Reviews.Author: Klisk
Reviews.Content: I really like this TV, actually. But I'm sending it back. It's not for me.The allure of this TV was the fact that it's a matte-version of the 650... However, I recently found out, it isn't. This is a 120mhz version of the 550. This uses an older processor than the 650. I'm a bit disappointed by that, and the lack of an extra HDMI port. The PQ isn't as stunning as the 650, predominately because of the older processor, not because of the semi-matte finish.However. Glossy does give you better blacks. This TV has pretty grey-colored blacks, which annoys me. It also suffers from clouding/flashlighting, unlike the 650 I've used.I did buy this version because I wanted to avoid reflections... I also bought the 650 for my Mom. Her TV is just plain out nicer. The reflections? Not a big difference. You see the reflections on both TV's. This one just diffuses them with the semi-matte. But you can still see yourself during dark scenes! It's just not as clear.Compared to the 650, the difference between glare is minimal. It's there, but minimal. You see yourself either way, might as well get the better picture!My opinion? If you REALLY hate glare, then the 630 is for you. However, if you're just WORRIED about glare... Go with the 650. You will be much happier in the long run.This TV, the 630, is a great TV. I just feel like, for the money, you're not getting the 'newest' tech. Samsung treats their matte-users like second-rate customers, and for good reason: People prefer glossy. Might as well go glossy, and have the best technology, rather than having something older with matte. I do believe matte can give an outstanding picture... Samsung just doesn't think it's worth their time.Honestly: If this TV is for a living room with a large window, then godspeed. It's for you. If this TV is for any other situation, then the 650 is probably your choice.

Reviews.Title: Choosing between the LN46A550, LN46A650 and LN46A630?
Reviews.Author: Matthew J
Reviews.Content: When researching LCD TVs, I narrowed my search to the Samsung 5- and 6-series, based on reviews of quality and overall value. I went to our local Best Buy several times to also let my eyes judge in person what I had been reading.First, I'd like to say that all three of these TVs are quality units, but each has a different feature set and if you are in the same situation I was, hopefully this review will help you make an informed decision.LN46A550 (Released March 2008): Great TV for those on a tight budget who still want one of best pictures available on any 46" LCD TV. Initially, this was my choice based on strong reviews and the savings it offered. The 550 has a matte screen, which reduces the reflection of ambient light and glare. I decided to narrow my search to the 6-series based on 120Hz processing (not available on the 550), which is a feature I wanted after seeing it in person, especially for Blu-ray movies and watching sports.LN46A650 (Released March 2008): Offering Auto Motion Plus 120hz and 50,000:1 contrast ratio, I initially thought this was an excellent choice. However, the 650 suffers from the same problem as plasma TVs, in that they reflect ambient light and significantly increase glare. Samsung chose to use a super glossy surface for their higher end LCD TVs, which increases contrast ratio at the cost of heavy reflection. Personally, one of the main reasons I was buying an LCD over a plasma was to eliminate glare. Samsung offers the PN50A650 for nearly the same price as the LN46A650, and you get a larger screen with 1,000,000:1 contrast ratio.LN46A630 (Released August 2008): The first thing you might notice is that Samsung released the 630 five months after the 550 and 650. The reason for this was consumers wanted a 120Hz Samsung LCD in a matte-finish screen. Also, people were quite mixed in their opinion of the red Touch of Color (ToC) frame and thick bezel. The 630 provides a thinner bezel and mutes the ToC. I much prefer this look, both when the TV is on and off, so I'm very happy with the adjustments. As mentioned, this LCD uses the matte-finish, which eliminates the reflection of ambient light and glare. It was interesting when I was in Best Buy, because they had a 650 and a 630 side-by-side. Both picture quality was very sharp (40,000:1 vs 50,000:1), although the 650 reflected light from several sources. I actually stood right in between the two screens and moved to the left and right. When I was in front of the 630, I could not see any reflections and the picture was extremely clear. As I slowly moved to the left in front of the 650, my face and body reflected off the screen like a mirror, as well as other light sources. During bright scenes this was not noticeable and the picture was very good, but during dark scenes the reflection was very distracting. The 630 had none of these issues, with the same advantages of excellent picture quality and 120 Hz processing.I think this LCD is the best combination of quality and value available right now. Amazon.com has really separated themselves from all other retailers with no tax, free shipment and free white glove delivery. Speaking of which, delivery was excellent. Even without all of these features, Amazon.com is still cheaper than all stores by hundreds of dollars.The sound of the 630 is average out of the box, so I have a home theater in a box (HTIB) hooked up to it. This is pretty common for most LCDs, except the very high end models.Overall, I think the LN46A630 is the best choice among Samsung LCDs, in terms of price, picture quality and features. If you are trying to decide between the 550, 650 and 630, I highly recommend the LN46A630.

Reviews.Title: One of the best LCD Displays available
Reviews.Author: T. Mowbray "Hunter Blackmoon"
Reviews.Content: Samsung LN46A630 46-Inch 1080p 120Hz LCD HDTV with Red Touch of Color[...] The condition of the unit is amazing considering the price I paid for it. There was no dust, no sticker residue, there is nothing that can be seen to be wrong with the unit. The only blemish on the unit is some very faint scratches on the console but you have to get right on top of it with a very bright light to make them out. The screen it self is perfect with no dead pixels. I was able to register the unit on the Samsung site and got an additional three months of warranty.My initial choices came down between the 46" and 52" Samsung models of 650 and 850. Because I got defrauded om the auction site for $[...] I had that much less to work with so I decided on the 46". Between the three different models I ruled out the 850 since it was a bit pricey. I was going to get the 650 but after reading the glare issues and checking it out myself at a local retailer I ultimately decided on the 630. One of the uses of the unit is for PS3 gaming and if any you have the Eye of Judgement you know that room has to be pretty bright.The picture of the 630 is outstanding. PS3 games look amazing. Blue-ray content is breathtaking. Standard DVDs are wonderful as well with upscaling. I use standard DirecTV over a component connection and while it is no where as good as even an upscale standard DVD it is suffice for viewing. I would upgrade to the DirecTV HD service but I do not like the idea of having to pay $[...] up front for a receiver PLUS a monthly lease fee on top of the HD service fee.The unit has a crap load of features and more than enough connections. I currently run the DTV over component into my home theater, PS3 over HDMI 1, my PC over HDMI 2 and my home theater system over HDMI 3. Changing inputs is a breeze and adjusting the picture is just as easy.The colors and picture quality is great. There are pre-set modes for your picture and sound but you can fully adjust both if you wish. The Standard and Movie modes are suffice for normal viewing but if you really have the need to burn out your eyes just turn on the dynamic mode. The only issue I have with any of these HD screens is the brightness of the whites. I have same issue with my LG computer monitor. The dynamic modes are great for gaming and 720/1080 movies but not so good for say web surfing or anything that has a white background or allot of white in general.The black levels seem to be one of the biggest issues with any LCD display. While the 630 does not present the deep black levels of a high quality plasma the levels it does produce are more than suffice and of great quality. You are able to adjust your black level and really should have no issues unless you turn on the dynamic mode but even with it on the black levels are still very deep. Out of the many LCD models I looked into I have to say the 630 has some best black levels available for an LCD screen.The audio quality of the 630 leaves a bit to be desired. It seems that Samsung can make great displays but are completely lost when it comes to audio; this can be seen (actually heard) in nearly all their TVs and audio systems. The audio from 630 should suffice for the majority of users but even a low priced non-Samsung audio system will make a huge difference. Because audio was not a factor in any of my display choices it will not be factored in my rating of this unit.If you decide to hook your PC up to this display do not use the VGA connection. Go with a DVI to HDMI connector or a DVI to HDMI cable. The only reason to use the VGA connection is if your video card only supports VGA, and in that case it is definitely time to upgrade your video card. I am big RTS gamer and currently use two LG 22" in dual screen mode for most gaming. I have 4 DVI connections (2 video cards) so I decided to hook up the 630 more for a laugh than anything and I'll tell you that there is no way I am going to unhook it!! It is outstanding on games, streaming video and DVD/BD video since I have BD player in the PC as well as the PS3. If your a Supreme Commander player and get this display you will be in heaven. World in Conflict and PS3 End War look even better.The 120hz is iffy for me. I am not big sports guy so I can't really comment on any motion blur as I have not seen any with or without the 120hz on. I have not noticed any motion blur in any fast paced FPS gaming either. I decided to keep the 120hz at the medium setting and there has been no issues. The 4ms of the unit only shows up when I get nuke happy in SupCom, WoC or go RPG crazy in GTA IV but it is minor.In the end after taking everything into account I would highly recommend the Samsung series 6 to anyone who wants a great HD display. If more connections are needed and glare is not a factor go with the 650 but if glare is a factor than the 630 is the best choice. I will also mention that the ToC on the 650 is far more visible than on the 630. If you have the extra cash than the 850 is an even better choice over the 650. The one for sure is that Samsung makes a great display and because they mass produce them they can often be found for a much lower price than their competitors.

Reviews.Title: Beautiful HDTV, great Tuner, Failed within 24 Hours
Reviews.Author: JP
Reviews.Content: Samsung have great looking HDTV's. For its size this TV is relatively light in weight.Setup is really very easy with a prompted preset for Home Setup or Store setup. This avoids bringing the TV home and not getting what you saw at the store (Under store lights the color and contrast are very different).Over the air HD programs in 1080i are really stunning, text is so sharp and well defined with no ghosting (better than one will get through cable, and it's free!). The detail that can be seen on weather radar images at 1080i is phenomenal, it's like reading a topo map, its so detailed and clear!! Will have to get a blu-ray player to get the best video quality as well, I have only seen true 1080p in the store on this set with blu-ray and it looked really good. On a test pattern I saw white lines between black gradients, the sharpening and black enhancement features seem to cause this, don't over do these settings. If you goof it up beyond recall, there is a factory reset, so don't be scared to experiment.The angle of viewing is very critical with this TV. If one doesn't position oneself just right the colors fade and blacks turn grey. At the optimal angle the colors and blacks are wonderful.The Digital tuner is very sensitive and brings in channels other Digital tuners in my home cannot, and brings in all stronger channels at 100%. The program guide is a little disappointing, Samsung did a much nicer job on their set top HD converter box with this feature.(Tip for those considering Over-the-air digital TV, get a decent antenna, and dedicate one antenna for each TV, digital tuners don't like splitters and boosters). Amazon sell great antennas for less than $40 (Search for DB2, DB4 or DB8). One annoying feature of the auto tune is that it grabs both Analog and Digital versions of the same channel, requiring one to delete the analog channel to make channel surfing more pleasant. I didn't see a way to avoid this. After February 2009 this will be a moot point.The PIP feature is a disappointment. The second picture must come from a different source than the main picture, and also must be analog. PIP is not available if you activate V-Chip either. If you want PIP, this NOT the right TV.Like the review that William T. Reach wrote here at Amazon, the unit failed very soon after being purchased (the very next day) and went into a cycle of turning itself on and off continuously. It failed watching a TV show, blanked out and never came on again. Because this TV failed so quickly (and others have had the exact same issue) I can only give 3 stars. The local retailer was happy to swap out once they saw what it was doing (they seemed very familiar with the diagnostic light patterns). Fingers crossed this time. If it fails again then it will be refund time. I'll post an update if it does fail again.The remote is easy to use, however there is no way to operate the TV without the remote (typical with DTV's these days). Being a new TV, only high end universal remotes like the Harmony will work with this TV, so don't lose the remote or tear it up.One frustration is that it is not possible to adjust the TV's settings or modes while viewing still pictures on a USB drive, for some reason this is disabled. This sucked for me because I wanted to use a monitor calibration image I use on computers to accurately set black/white points and gamma. So had to eyeball the setup in the room while wathcing a show. The TV has different settings such as Cinema and sports, they really should let you change this setting when looking at stills, they are different to regular TV signals.If Samsung can improve their build quality, they have a winner here.

Reviews.Title: Great TV
Reviews.Author: Don L. Hopkins "DLH"
Reviews.Content: I researched LCD's for a while and then when I saw Samsung recommended on Consumer Reports, I decided to go with that brand (although there are plenty and they all look good at the stores). CR had the LN46A550 listed, but when we got to the store, the LN46A630 was available for a few hundred more dollars, but had the 120Hz, higher contrast ratio, and faster reponse time. I found the SD viewing terrible, but attribute it to the cable reception/quality, not the TV. The HD programs and Blue Ray are incredible. I wasn't aware the 650 was "glossy" vs. matte, but we do have a bright room and there is not an issue, so I'm glad we chose the 630. Fantastic TV!

Reviews.Title: Amazon is GREAT
Reviews.Author: Christopher M. Berry "Skeptic and researcher"
Reviews.Content: I have been in the business of home theater and home automation for 6 years. I have looked at plasmas, rear projection, and in the last few years, really into the LCD market. I sale these items to customers on a weekly basis, so research is a must. I purchased this TV last week and it is fabulous. I have no buyers-remorse from this purchase. It is an outstanding set, and has a beautiful picture. I have to give Amazon an A+ for the process of this purchase. Like I stated, I work in this business, and Amazon had a better price than my suppliers could give to me through my company. I bought the TV online on Tuesday night, and the delivery was estimated to be 5-9 days. The order tracking abilities on Amazon are wonderful, and the delivery service (Pilot) delivered the TV on Friday. That's three buisiness days after I purchased. I was able to install my new surround sound room with the TV on Sunday before the family get-together for the holidays. Everyone raved about how great it looked, and it is not even calibrated properly yet. I have bought books and movies from Amazon before, and like this purchase, I have not been dissapointed yet. Feel good about buying through this site, and know you will be happy.

Reviews.Title: Great HDTV
Reviews.Author: holson
Reviews.Content: Excellent results with Amazon's white glove service, however it's 4 hour delivery window for those who work meant Saturday delivery for me. Set works average on analog cable signals, better on digital cable and fantastic on 720p cable TV, DVD upconverted and Blu-ray, had a slight green push which I corrected. In my living room this set works better then the 650, not as reflective. The audio is ok, use it mostly with a AV receiver. The Easy Set-Up guide is useless, but the TV walks you through it. Remote has keys poorly located so touching the mute could also change the source, not good.

Reviews.Title: Outstanding HDTV
Reviews.Author: Mike
Reviews.Content: We purchased this set after much research on features and price.  Spent a lot of time looking at both this set and the 650.  There was a definite positive difference with glare over the 650.  The two sets are basically the same minus 1 HDMI output and the difference in "Dynamic Contrast Ratio" is negligable and certainly not noticeable to the eye.  The screen reflection (glare) off the 650 was unacceptable when compared to the 630.Ordering & Delivery was seamless and the unit was set up in the house six days after placing the order.  No sales tax, free white glove shipping, and $550 discount off MSRP was a heck of a deal even if the price drops some after the Xmas season it was at the price point we were waiting for.  I have a 60" Sony Grand Wega that has consistently been an outstanding HDTV and remains such in our our entertainment room.  This set for half of what we paid a few years ago for the Sony is unbelieveably beyond the great picture and performance of the Sony.  I highly recommend this set to anyone looking for the WOW HDTV experience!  Ordering and shipping (via CEVA) with Amazon was as easy as going to Best Buy or any other retail outlet and having them deliver it.  Except you save the shipping and sales tax.  Very happy with Samsung, CEVA and Amazon.

Reviews.Title: ln46a630 with matte screen
Reviews.Author: Thunderxgb
Reviews.Content: Great tv! still figuring out all the bells and whistles, love the matte screen perfect for my bright livingroom....dont count on the white glove delivery tho, its kind of a joke. I had a fellow about 72 tried to deliver my tv.  He got it off the truck which took awhile btw, but then i used his cart and brought it up the driveway to the front door myself where i signed the bill and he left. I dragged it in the house and unboxed it and set it up myself. While it didnt take alot of effort, dont let amazon blow smoke about its "white glove delivery service".

Reviews.Title: HTPC Users Beware!
Reviews.Author: Christopher Constantakis
Reviews.Content: I have updated my review with a comparison to the 650 series Samsung at the bottom.Original Review:-------------------------------------------------------------------------------I would like to start off by saying that I had been eying a Samsung LCD tv for quite some time. When I finally purchased it I felt content with the knowledge that I would be getting a high quality set from a good manufacturer. Overall this is the case except for on major issue!If you will be connecting this TV to a computer like I do you must be aware there is an issue with the Auto Motion Plus(AMP) setting. It is always enabled when the TV is started no matter what is set in the menu. The only way to disable it is to go through the menu and enable then disable the setting. This is what I have to do each time the TV is turned on. I find this unacceptable. The 650 series had a similar issue that has been fixed with a firmware update but us 630 owners are ignored. There is a PC mode that can be used if you connect the computer through HDMI2. It is supposed to help with lag by disabling many of the extra processing including AMP but even in this setting the problem persists!To those wondering what AMP is it is the the de-judder processor used to smooth out video. It interpolates frames to smooth scenes with fast motion of long pans. Many people dislike it because it makes everything look too smooth; this is referred to as the "soap opera effect". I have contacted Samsung about this issue and will update my review with the outcome. If it is not fixed shortly Amazon or Samsung will be picking up this set and I will be spending my money elsewhere. I hate to feel this way because other then this one issue the TV is great.-------------------------------------------------------------------------------UPDATE: I would like to thank Amazon for being so good about the return. They picked up my TV and I then ordered the LN46A650. The only issue is that I am still waiting for the refund. I contacted their TV returns department and was told it normally takes around 3 weeks for the refund. It is not a big issue but I want people to be aware.Having now spent some time with both TV's I feel that I am in a good positing for some important comparisons.First I have been surprised by how much better the 650 looks in comparison to the 630. The 630 had some ghosting issues that are not apparent at all with the 650. My girlfriend even noticed which says a lot!Second, the gloss of the 650 is not as bad as I expected. It does not detract from my viewing and I can see how it increases contrast and "pop" with the image. Having said that, I would still like a slightly more matte finish.Third, the issues with the AMP bug I had with the 630 are not present with the 650. I was a bit worried but am pleased to say that when I turn AMP off on the 650 it stays that way.The remote on the 650 has a Ipod like wheel that can be used to navigate the menus which I don't like. It can still be clicked in the 4 major positions like a normal menu button but I still found the 630 remote to be better. The menu navigation on the 650 is also a bit slower from some reason. There is a much more noticeable lag with the interface.Overall unless you have an extremely bright area I would recommend the 650 series hands down over the 630. That is not to say the 630 is a bad set but the 650 is simply better. The major reason for my upgrade were the issues with AMP and HTPC's, but the overall increase in image quality was a very pleasant benefit. I hope that my bad fortune will help others in a similar situation and might also help those who are on the fence between this set and the 650 make a educated decision.

Reviews.Title: Great screen
Reviews.Author: W. Dormann
Reviews.Content: I specifically purchased this TV because of the matte screen.  Later models have more inputs and some additional features, but they also go for the glossy screen.  While this bumps up the contrast ratio, it reportedly increases the effects of glare.  Picture quality is amazing, 120Hz is great for movies, as it's an even multiple of 24fps.  Combined with an upscaling Oppo 971H DVD player, I don't see a need for Blu-Ray at all, actually. 120Hz plus anti-judder/smooth motion is great for sports.  The nice thing is that the TV remembers the settings based on the input that you are using.  For example, my DVD HDMI input has Smooth Motion turned off, and my TV Coax input has it turned on.I was concerned about the Touch of Color being distracting, but honestly, I can't even tell that it's there.After about a month of use, I can say that I don't have a single complaint.

Reviews.Title: Great Experience & Great TV
Reviews.Author: bmorton "bmorton"
Reviews.Content: So, I was doing everything in my power NOT to buy a TV from Amazon.  Not because I don't like Amazon but because to me... you just buy a $1350 TV from Sears or Bestbuy.  You know, a store you can take it back to and complain if the thing is a dud.  Well, I tried and tried to give Sears or Bestbuy my money for this TV and for several other models (Sony Z series and the LG 70 series).  I started looking for a TV so I could watch the Super Bowl in HD.  Started the search after getting back from the AFC Championship game in Pittsburgh and I was on a mission!  So, several trips to Sears (two seperate locations) and multiple trips to Bestbuy (again, more than one location)... and I had nothing!  The people at Sears basically told me there was no way they could get me a TV for the Super Bowl (it was still almost two weeks away at this point!!!) and Bestbuy was doing everything in thier power to sell me a TV that was $700 more than I wanted to spend.  By 1/22/09, I was really beginning to wonder if I'd have a TV for the game. Destiny intervened at that point.  I got an e-mail from Amazon that guarenteed TV's ordered on the 22nd would be there in time for the game. My sister had ordered the same model from Amazon and had great success so I decided to go for it.  Well, the TV came with two days to spare, the shipping was free and the service was great.  The TV is great.  Great picture, great connectivity, and great for a room with a lot of ambient light.  This model has a matte finish screen which is different than most Samsungs. That matte screen makes all the difference in a room with a lot of light.  There are too many settings to figure out on your own so I went online and found out how many other owners had callibrated this model (Bestbuy was really excited about selling me the same service for $250).  Callibrating the set made a big difference and only took about 20 minutes. I recommend reading some of the posts of other owners as there's a wealth of information about how to callibrate this model for different needs/likes/applications. At this point, I've had the tv for less than a week but it has been great thus far.  It was amazing to watch the Steelers win the Super Bowl in HD.  At one point during the game, I believe I hugged the TV. It's an intuitive design so I was able to get most things going right out of the box.  I did hook up a sound bar (Yamaha YAS-71) and was please with the combination.To me, the point here is two-fold.  One, it's OK to buy a TV online (saves money and the hassle of dealing with so-called "experts" at the local retailer).  Second, the Samsung 630 is a tremendous value and its a great overall TV.  The picture was as good as anything I saw during a three day, six store marathon search for a 46" LCD in central Illinois.

Reviews.Title: Worked for 1 month, wating on Samsung to come out and repair
Reviews.Author: J. Tanner
Reviews.Content: UPDATE 2/2/09:Repairs were made on 1/30 as scheduled, the power board had failed.  Yes, Samsung made the repairs as promised but it's the point that a brand new TV stopped working after one month.  I would purchase Samsung again but I'd do a little more research (and read the bad reviews, not just the good ones) next time to determine if there were potential issues with the model I was considering.ORIGINAL POST 1/28/09:I purchased this TV on 12/21/08 and on 1/25/09 it shut off by itself and will not turn back on.  I put in a service request online to Samsung on 1/26, had to call them on 1/27 because it was assigned to an incorrect service center (FL when I am in GA) for in home service.  While on the call the Samsung representative faxed the authorization to the local service center.  Checked online again this morning 1/28 and the work is not scheduled until 1/30.  They better have all the parts to fix it then because of the big game on Sunday!  I'll update this post once the problem has been diagnosed and fixed.  It is unacceptable to be dealing with this one month after the purchase date.Before it stopped working it was a great TV, used it with DirecTV HD service and PS3 blu-ray player.Note that I did not purchase from Amazon, got it from a retail store.

Reviews.Title: Amazing
Reviews.Author: A. Ferguson
Reviews.Content: This is my first HDTV and... wow.  The first time I saw a Blu-ray on this TV I nearly cried it was so beautiful.  It's amazing to me that a technology of this quality is affordable to your typical consumer.  I've now owned this TV for about a month and it's still capable of producing that jaw dropping effect.  The only real downside to this TV is I find myself not wanting to do anything but watch it.  I've been running a PS3, a DirectTV HD receiver, and my computer into the TV (via an Onkyo 606) and they all look amazing on this TV.  The ability to use the TV as a monitor is a huge plus in my opinion.I've been watching the reviews and the prices on this TV, and other comparable models, since making this purchase and, honestly, I think for this level of quality there isn't a better deal out there.  The LN46A650 is the more popular TV.  I went for the 630 because I didn't think the extra $100 (at the time I made the purchase) was worth slightly better colors and an ethernet and HDMI port, especially if it meant having to deal with reflections.  The colors on this TV are phenomenal, so I'm pretty sure went the right route.At the time I bought this TV, it was less expensive than purchasing at Best Buy and Circuit City by $150 (and included free shipping).  It took less than a week to be delivered (ordered on Monday arrived on Friday).  Incredible when you consider that it was ordered right less than 2 weeks before X-mas.  The delivery man helped me bring it in to the house but told me he wasn't supposed to help me get it out of the box and put it somewhere.  I didn't really care much about that level of service but if you do, that might be something you want to consider (I mean, they brought it all the way in to my living room, I don't mind taking over from there).Haven't had the experience of dealing with Samsung's warranty service (and hope I don't have to) so I can't comment on that.  I also don't know how long this TV will hold up.  But its so worth it right now.  Highly recommend!

Reviews.Title: Incredible picture
Reviews.Author: Jamie Molaison
Reviews.Content: Just received an A630, and all is well so far.  To use an exhausted phrase--the picture really jumps off the screen.  Crisp, bright, and vibrant.  I wasn't expecting to be blown away, but the enhancements on this unit are truly evident.  That could be due in part to my upgrading from a rear projection TV.I really went back and forth on the matte vs. gloss issue (A630 vs. A650).  Definitely made the right choice for a standard living room with three windows.  The reflections would just kill the experience for me.  And if you're worried about stepping down from 50000:1 to 40000:1 in dynamic contrast, I wouldn't.  I can't see why anyone would want more than the max available here.The picture is too good at times, exposing the deficiencies of my cable signal.  This, I feel, will be the only drawback; one I can certainly live with.  Hopefully, the source technology will catch up soon.  I can't wait to see a Blu-ray disc on this puppy...

Reviews.Title: Great TV
Reviews.Author: Naresh Chebolu "Samsung"
Reviews.Content: I like the TV a lot esp for my living room which has lots of windows, It was a tossup between the a650 which has the glossy finish vs the 630. Decided to go with the a630 cause the reflections of 650 were too harsh for my liking. The only thing lacking vs the 650 is 1 HDMI port and LAN connection

Reviews.Title: This is an outstanding TV
Reviews.Author: Chaz "CM"
Reviews.Content: Well my 43 inch plasma crashed and after months of watching my 17 inch Panasonic, it was time to step up and buy something new. I think i read every review and visited the big retail stores several times before deciding on this model. This was my choice not only because of the outstanding image but also because of its sports car looks. I have to admit that the top of the line Sony i liked a bit better and on a scale from 1-10 i would give the Samsung a 9 and the sony z class a 9.5. I just didnt feel like paying the 600.00 difference being the samsung was the best bang for the buck. All in all i am satisfied with this display. As others have mentioned the matted screen is great in rooms that are bright. I have a large window behind the couch but again the matted screen helps cut down on glare. The only small complaint i do have on this tv is it doesn't come with a small light around or on the brand name on the front bottom of the display. I thought all samsung touch of color tv's have this feature, but when i called the factory they said this particular model didn't have it. One other thing..if you ever have the opportunity to get your tv calibrated by a certified IFS technician, do it. The improvement over the factory settings are night and day difference. Best buy in my area had 2 tv's same brand on display, one calibrated and the other wasnt. It was like watching a vcr and dvd side by side. Yes the calibration is that good. The cost is around 300.00 in my area. You can bet that this will be my next upgrade.

Reviews.Title: Perfect
Reviews.Author: B Yo
Reviews.Content: Ya have to be a bit nervous when ordering an item of this size and value  on-line.  The item showed up in ½ the time expected, in perfect condition and by a most courteous delivery person.  Really couldn't ask for much more.

Reviews.Title: Samsung LN46A630
Reviews.Author: R. W. Nichols
Reviews.Content: TVis excellent. Meet all our expectations. Amazon delivery and set up was perfect. We give the experience the highest recommendation.

Reviews.Title: Planned obsolescence at its finest
Reviews.Author: Will
Reviews.Content: I bought this TV 2 years ago - it comes with 12 years parts and labor, and my credit card extends the warranty on electronics by another year.  At 2 years and 2 months, the picture on my tv started to go screwy all at once.  The picture would be normal for a while, and then suddenly the whole screen would go extremely white and almost wash out completely.  I called customer service and they determined it was a hardware issue, and because I was out of warranty, I would have to pay for the replacement control board and service out of pocket.  All in all the cost of the repairs would have been hundreds of dollars.For a device I paid over a thousand dollars for, I was pretty frustrated that the product just ceased to function pretty much as soon as the warranty was up.  This TV is not well made, and not well supported.  I don't recommend you buy this unless you are also able to buy it with a long extended purchase protection program.

Reviews.Title: My Samsung TV - Beware!
Reviews.Author: kevin ray mcconnell
Reviews.Content: I purchased this TV for Christmas in December of 2008, paying a little over 1300 dollars.  No problems for 2 years.  Then, a little over 2 years later, a red shadowy tinge invaded the screen.  It was not very distracting at first, but has become more prevalent as the months passed.  When I noticed the issue in March 2011, I contacted Samsung.  They issued a repair ticket, but explained that becasue the TV was out of warranty- I would be responsible for the repair cost.  The repair shop explained that it would be cheaper just to buy a new one than repair this one.  He also explained that this is a fairly commion issue with this model.  I begrudgingly lived with this until this week.  The picture is so bad that the TV is almost unwatcheable at times.  I again complained to Samsung, and even attached a pic of the screen.  I explained that even though the TV is out of warranty, Samsung TV's should last for more than 2 years.  I asked them to stand by their product.  Samsung's response:Dear Kevin Mcconnell,Thank you for contacting Samsung Electronics.We understand your concern that your TV had developed a red tinge on the screen, and we are sorry to inform you that,Samsung or any other company will not stand by the customer, if their units are out of warranty.Looking back, I would have purchased the extended warranty had I known that the TV would only have 2 years of life.  However, I paid more for the Samsung brand, expecting that the TV would be of better quality than some of the others I looked at.When I get ready to replace this TV- it will not be a Samsung, and I will fork out the extra dough for the extended warranty.

Reviews.Title: BLACK SCREEN SYNDROME
Reviews.Author: Amadeo Castillo Vasquez
Reviews.Content: After one year and half of use, the TV's screen goes black.When you turn on the TV around two hours the screen goes black - thevideo disappear, some time the  video comes again... you can listen the sound, you canchange channels, go into menus, etc. but no video on the screen. If you turn off the TV and turn ON immediately the problem disappear for few minutes. This TV was always used connected to uninterrupted Power Supply (UPS).Now the TV is out of warranty and the representative in my country doesn't give support to equipment they didn't sold , so I'm really regretful of bought a SANSAMG TV.

Reviews.Title: bad purchase
Reviews.Author: D. Moawad "daliasf"
Reviews.Content: would have loved to give it zero stars! i bought this tv in december 2008. from day 1, it had problems with pixelation, every now and then, red and green pixel lines showed up but then disappeared. they appeared with cable, with dish network channels and with DVDs. now, it's august 2009, and this tv has turned into a completely useless piece of furntiture, the screen is entirely red with occasional green, and almost no visible image. a diagnostic visit from a place like best buy will cost 150$ on sale, cable technicians came out twice and were not sure of the problem. it's just not what i expect of a brand name like samsung, i dropped 1500$ on this set, and would expect it to work perfectly right out of the box. now, 8 months later, im already thinking of a new major purchase to save msyelf the headache of dealing with parts, technicians, diagnostics, not to metion the hours of aggravation over the phone with call centers. this time maybe a plasma tv. this was a bad purchase.

Reviews.Title: Terrible television
Reviews.Author: D. Ellis
Reviews.Content: For the first two years I loved this television.  The picture was fantastic, better than any of the other LCDs.  Recently we were watching the television and the picture quality became very poor.  The screen was bleached out and there were shadows around the people on the television.  I contacted Samsung and they stated I needed to contact Best Buy or Sears to have them fix it.  With the warranty expired Samsung was no longer interested in me as a customer.  I did contact the GeekSquad and they inspected my television.  The verdict was that it was going to cost me $400 to fix the television.  I contacted Samsung and they did not want to here about the television.  The television was only 26 months old at the time of the issue.

Reviews.Title: Very good (but not quite perfect) TV - white glove delivery is terrific
Reviews.Author: Ricks picks
Reviews.Content: This is a very good TV, but so far, the picture quality does not seem to be quite as good as some of the other 40" Samsung LCD TVs that I have.  It may be that it is the matt screen, the size of the screen itself, the room it is in, or perhaps I have not yet gotten the adjustments quite right -- while the picture is certainly at least "very good" it is not quite as "crisp and clear" and does not quite have the "pop" of my other (smaller and older, but with glossy screens) Samsung HDTVs.  I actually think it is most likely the matt screen, which seems to dull the picture just slightly.  At the same time, if you have glare issues, this is the HDTV to purchase -- I would purchase this HDTV again without hesitation.The white glove delivery was professional and flawless.  They called and made an appointment and arrived on-time.  Brought it into the house, helped me set it up, waited till I had checked to make sure it was working, and then took away all the packaging.  What more could I possibly hope for?

Reviews.Title: awesome !
Reviews.Author: T. Lawrence
Reviews.Content: I've been shopping and watching prices for 8 months and finally decided on the Samsung 630 over the 650 and I couldn't be happier !  The colors are amazing and the picture is 3D like. The TV was delivered quickly and free !  My first Amazon experience was awesome !  I love my TV !

Reviews.Title: Even Better Then Expected - and I expected a lot!
Reviews.Author: Michael Kadous
Reviews.Content: I did a lot of research on the type of LCD I wanted to buy.  I knew 46" was the size and I had heard rumor that 120Hz was the way to go.  I read all the reviews and balanced them against the price.  The LN46A530 is the perfect fit.  The picture is incredible.  The sound is spectacular.  For those who speak to sound issues...my guess is that they are using componant video for picture and regular left/right audio for sound.  I however use the HDMI cable...and well, all I can say is sound and picture are wonderful.  Some have spoken to the fact that the 120Hz makes every show/ad/video look as if you're watching a soap opera where you feel like you're in the room. Yes, this is true.  The picture is so sharp that it almost has a 3D affect.  However, this TV gives you the flexibility to slow down the affect and this is useful.  The touch of red around the sides is just that.  Just a touch.  I can barely notice it.  So if you're thinking not buying this TV because of the color...don't let that detur you.  It should have no bearing.If you're wavering, make the purchase.  You won't regret it.I love it and show it off all the time.

Reviews.Title: Excellent TV...amazing picture!!
Reviews.Author: M. Hall
Reviews.Content: Awesome TV for the $$...only paid $1349.00 for this TV.  Originally bought the Samsung 40A630 from CC for $1200+tax, but realized it was too small for my living/great room and returned it (luckily before they shut down).  If you think a 46'' is too big, think again....IT IS NOT!  Out of the box I thought it was huge, but after hanging it on the wall it was the perfect size.  I could have went even bigger, but my budget said no.  Also, don't bother with a Vizio LCD as the picture won't compare to that of a Samsung especially the 630 series. I was almost set on buying a Vizio due to the value (I thought) but once I saw the Samsung and Vizio side by side, there was no comparison. Much deeper blacks, better contrast, better picture, better off angle viewing, etc.  Anyway, don't bother spending forever researching TV's like I did, just go look at a Samsung and be done with it.  Buying from Amazon.com is easy and RELIABLE!  Enjoy.

Reviews.Title: Superior Picture. Other features lacking
Reviews.Author: M. Mickley
Reviews.Content: Love the picture. Superior (after quite a bit of adjustments) but wish I could say more about the rest of the TV. I had it and the Sony KDL-46V4100 side by side (came down to Samsung or it) in my living room and the Samsung has a better picture. Barely. Bluer blues, darker blacks, slightly better color separation. However, that's where the superiority ends. The Samsung's sound, as written in other reviews, isn't that great. The remote is huge and not programmable so can't control my dish Network receiver like Sony's can. The TV's manual controls are molded in the lower right-hand corner of the frame and are tiny, basically impossible to see or figure out where they are so don't lose or break the remote. Only three HDMI inputs, need it to have four. And the frame is still VERY shiny even though the screen is matte. Why would Samsung matte down the screen but leave the frame so shiny when people like me don't want the glare? In summary, everything about the TV except for the screen I really don't like. But since I'm buying an HDTV for the picture it's a keeper 'cause the picture IS the best. Just wish Samsung had done a better job with the other items.

Reviews.Title: Good TV, good value, except the viewing angle...
Reviews.Author: dave999z
Reviews.Content: This issue has been covered extensively on the AVS forum.  Supposedly, Samsung has been shipping some of its 2008 TV models with panels (screens) from three different manufacturers.  You can tell which one you have by the sticker on the side of the set that says "Version ____."  The first letter = the panel type ("S", "A", or "C").  (Example: "Version AA02" means you have an "A" panel.  You can also tell on the back of the set: look at the model number, then there is a space, then the letter A,C, or S.)  Apparently, "S" panels are manufactured by Samsung (in Korea?) and use Samsung's SPVA technology, while "A" and "C" are outsourced (to Taiwan?) and don't even use the same pixel structure (if you take a close-up picture of the screens, the pixels look completely different).  Apparently, all 650s are "S" panels, and all 52-inch 630s are "S" panels.  But with the 46-inch 630s it seems that early on in the production run they were "S" panels (so that is what the pro reviewers and magazines likely based their reviews on and that is what seems to be on all showroom floors), in the fall it was somewhat of a lottery, now they seem to all be "A" panels.  (I purchased one very recently from Amazon, and it's an "A" panel.)The issue with the "A" panels is that the color does not look as good off axis.  On mine, once my viewing angle is greater than 20-30 degrees horizontal or 15-20 degrees vertical, there is a noticeable change in color (it looks slightly washed out, or pastel-like, or like there is a really thin white haze or something, hard to explain).  It does not look BAD, and it may be better than many other sets out there, certainly better than most LCD sets have been in recent years.  However... I looked at a 650 in person and the colors did not really change at all off angle.  I also looked at a 630 in person that was an "S" panel and the colors did fade off angle, but not as much as my "A" panel 630 seems to.Again, it's not a BIG problem.  I think the 630 is a fantastic set and a great value.  And this info from the Internet forums about the different panel versions may not be accurate (maybe it's just set-to-set variations, or subjectivity, who knows).  I'm just passing on what I learned in another forum.  And my own viewing test could be flawed.  But, that is my personal experience so thought people should know.  If viewing angle is one of the most important things to you and you're discriminating, then this may be relevant to you.  On the upside, I have not seen flashlighting or clouding or the other issues people commonly complain about with LCDs.  The 630, even my "A" panel, is a great TV, really great value.  But I wish the picture did not change (even a little bit) when vieiwing off angle.  If it didn't have that issue (which for me is pretty important, maybe not for you), it'd be 5 stars.I actually think I should give it 3.5 or 4 stars, because other than this issue, it's awesome.  but amazon doesn't let you change the rating.UPDATE (Feb 6 09):As I mentioned in the original part of this post (above), I am not too thrilled about the viewing angle of my "A" panel LN46A630. Am considering returning and getting a 650 instead. I went into BB today and took a long look at the 650 and how it looks off angle. It was an "S" panel, version SQ01. I must have walked back and forth a hundred times. They had a segment of Conan O'Brien that was like 5 minutes, and his face was on the screen the whole time, so it was a good test for how flesh tones change off axis. I observed that this 650 changed very significantly by 45 degrees. His face was orange dead center, and white at 45 degrees. It was a pretty linear loss of color as the viewing angle increased.I tried to do this same observation at CC last week, and thought then that the 650 looked really good off axis (better than a 630 "S" that was on display near it, and both seemed to be better than my 630 "A"). But there were a billion people there in the way and the video loop had very few faces, so it was hard to get a really good look. Today at BB I got a REALLY good look. I did it about 20 times (there were other segments with faces, not just Conan) to convince myself. I am convinced, the 650 "S" looked radically different (color-wise) at 45 degrees than straight on.They had a 530 (I think that's what it was, had a matte screen) "A" panel on display. It definitely changed off axis. Pretty much like my "A" 630 does.My 630 doesn't change in such a linear fashion as the 650 does, it seems to hold until about 20 degrees, then fades from about 20-30 degrees, then holds.I think the gloss on the 650 gives an appearance of the colors just exploding out of the screen, and that masks actual color changes somewhat, because the shine holds throughout.I am still on the fence. Maybe my 630 "A" panel is different, not necessarily worse than a 650 "S" (i.e., the 630 is a little worse off angle, but doesn't have the glare of the 650). Though now I'm starting to notice mild flashlights. Uggh.BTW, one thing I've noticed (not sure if it's been mentioned): in any model the off-axis color seems to be worse on the bigger screens than the smaller ones. Could be another factor to conflate people's observations.

Reviews.Title: Broke within minutes of turning it on...
Reviews.Author: D. Van Woerkom
Reviews.Content: I'm not one to be too harsh in a review, but the screen on this tv went green and white about 15 minutes after we started watching it with the kids.  Then it wouldn't turn back on (kept cycling on/off by itself until we had to unplug it).  We still ended up with a Samsung, but the initial experience wasn't pleasant.

Reviews.Title: Horrible Support
Reviews.Author: A. Putnam
Reviews.Content: It was nice while it lasted. It died in July. It is still broken.This is the saga of my still unresolved problem television. I would have never imagined that 3 months would pass and I would still be stuck with a dead television. Every time I think I have turned a corner that will bring me to the end, a fixed television it is not so.I should have never purchased a Samsung product. Plain and simple. I know this now. I purchased an LCD television and to make matters worse I purchased it from Sears. This was on 12/19/2009. I was happy. The TV worked and it looked good. Until it didn't. In late July of 2009 the TV would not power on correctly.- I called Samsung support because Sear's sales person told me it only had a manufacturer warranty unless I upgraded to theirs. We did some troubleshooting and the technician determined the problem. He said the parts will be shipped to me and I will call a technician who will visit and fix the TV.- A week passes and I do not see any parts. I call the repair company Samsung has contracted and they say the parts are back ordered. Okay I wait.- I wait a month and I see nothing. I check the status of my ticket online and it says the ticket is canceled. I call the repair company again. They say the parts are still on back order and suggest calling Samsung.- I call Samsung and the woman tells me the parts are back ordered. I ask here for an ETA. She says there is none. I ask her what good is my warranty if there are no parts to fix the TV. At this point it seems there is no intention of fixing my TV. The apathy pours out of my earphone. I finally tell her that I just wish to sell the useless TV back to them. She offers to arrange for Executive Customer Service to exchange the TV. Since it will never be fixed I settle for that.- After a week someone finally calls me. This is in early September. We exchange information. He says that he will prepare the exchange which will take a week (really?? a week) and then it will be sent to Sears to exchange the TV since I purchased it there. I ask how long all of this should take to get the TV. He says two weeks.- The next week I get a call from the same representative (I guess it does take a week) and he says the information has been sent to Sears and I should hear from them shortly, riiiiiiiiight.- I do not hear from them. I call Samsung for a status. They say they know nothing. This I do believe. I ask them to check with Sears on the status, maybe give a nudge.- Two weeks later there is no contact. I call Samsung and ask if I can have the contact information for the person at Sears receiving the exchange request and an RMA number. The woman gives me the RMA number but will not release the contact info. I ask her if she can contact them for a status. She says she can re-submit the request.- Still nothing. I try calling some Sears numbers and no one knows what an RMA number is. I am not joking. Everyone said they didn't even know what an RMA was.- A couple days later I get a call from I'm not sure if it was Sears, Samsung or an intermediary. She said she was from some company other than Sears or Samsung. They say they will contact someone at my local Sears store and make sure something happens.- Nothing happens. I decide to visit the store (09/04/09). I am told that nothing can be done until the department manager is back and he will be in on Saturday. I come in on Sautrday. He is not there. I come in on Monday. He is not in. I am told he will be in on Thursday. I come in on Thursday. He is in. I give him the RMA number from Samsung. He checks it and calls HQ. He says it is not a Sears RMA number and is probably a Samsung reference number. He asks me to call Samsung and see if they can e-mail the exchange information to him and he will try and take care of it. He gives me his card. I call Samsung and give them the info. They need a fax number. I get the fax number and call back the rep updates the ticket and I ask him if someone will e-mail/fax the info. He's says that he is sure someone is working on the ticket and it will be done.- (10/09/09) I am sure no one is working on it. No one ever has. Why would they now. I call Samsung. The women confirms that no one sent any information to the department manager at Sears. She says she will check with her manager to see if she can re-submit the request to Sears HQ (which has been done twice supposedly) and "maybe" in addition send it to the department manager. No promises, no hope, end of call.I have no idea what is going on. When I get on Samsung's site both tickets, the repair and exchange ticket are canceled (but I'm sure some one is working on it). I have never encountered such an infective system as Samsung's support service. I strongly recommend not buying a Samsung product. I will update this blog as more unfolds. I should have started this sooner but I could never have predicted such problems. In the meantime I relate my story to everyone I know, who are dismayed and affected. I am probably missing a lot of phone calls I have made but this is the meat of it.[...]

Reviews.Title: Just discussed  / Samsung LN46A630
Reviews.Author: Todd Awaugaman "T Waugaman"
Reviews.Content: When the  $1300 lcd TV arrived I hooked it all up and it would not turn on it did what others have said it would do turn off and on over and over... so I called Samsung they had me get in touch  with a local TV repair company. (They told me it would be about 2 weeks before someone could come look at it. )  For the price I paid for it and the time spent looking and comparing and the many hours spent on research on this TV, lets just say I was a little upset  getting a lemon when I should have gotten a Great product.  Today they picked up the TV I have had it in my home for about a week. (I hated looking at the box I am just discussed with  the entire process. )  I guess I will be happy with the 32" I already had... and wait on a great or better deal.I will say that everyone i talked to was helpfull...

Reviews.Title: Great product, AWFUL shipping
Reviews.Author: D. McWherter
Reviews.Content: So far, I love the TV.  The only complaint that I have is that Amazon shipped it via CEVA, which completely dropped the ball on delivery.  It made me wish more than anything that I just bought the TV locally, even if it was more expensive.CEVA scheduled to deliver the TV on 3 separate days before they managed to get the TV to my house.  Of course, on the first and second days, they waited until 1-2 hours *after* the 4 hour delivery window before notifying me that they weren't going to be coming.  On the 3rd day, they delivered the TV only an hour after the delivery window.  The 1st day, they claimed they had truck problems.  The 2nd day, they claimed a tree fell on their truck.  The 3rd day, they explained their lateness as a simple miscalculation.Of course, CEVA couldn't give me any information when I called them during and after the shipping window ended.  "Hi, the delivery window ended 30 minutes ago.  I'm just checking to see if you're still coming, so I know if I should keep waiting at my house for you" I'd ask.  They'd claim to try to contact the driver, but never managed to do so.The worst shipping experience of my life.  Awful service.

Reviews.Title: Works really well, until it doesn't.
Reviews.Author: Andy Oltman
Reviews.Content: After four years, two boards died and I had to spend over $3000 to replace them. Now, about 5 months later, I am starting to see the same symptoms that I did just before it died last time.But when it is working, the picture quality is really great and the feature set lends the unit to be very flexible to integrate into the rest of your entertainment system.I just wish these thing were designed to live 10 years or more, like the old CRT models were. Planned obsolescence.

Reviews.Title: I will never buy another Samsung
Reviews.Author: L. Lee
Reviews.Content: Last Saturday this  SAMSUNG LN46A630 :  bright red tinge, extreme contrast,  vertical lines like watching cartoons.I did get over 4-1/2 years out of it, that's $300 per year.  But my 1982 17" Sony Trinitron is still working great.Does any manufacturer build a reliable TV or anything??????  I have a feeling is NO.Even if I buy an expensive TV the manufacturer warranty is still a whopping 1 year.  Go figure.Seems now like everything is build to fail (plan obsolescence,  my washer and dryer, oven, AV receiver all had problems after a few years only.My conclusion, buy the less expensive TV (appliance, etc) and plan to buy every 3-4 years. (I guess it keeps the economy going)

Reviews.Title: TV just Died
Reviews.Author: Lancelot
Reviews.Content: This TV has been working for more than a few years and just the other night the color when haywire and has not returned to normal since. A tv of this calibur should not break in just a few years!

Reviews.Title: Works great!
Reviews.Author: svendog41
Reviews.Content: This is exactly what I was looking for at the right price and came on time.  I would recommend this item.

Reviews.Title: excellent set
Reviews.Author: BTElectronics
Reviews.Content: This is a really great TV. I have had it for 15 months now, and we have had not 1 problem with it. It is the center of my home theatre system. I paid almost $1500 for it, and now in 2010, 46" LCD's are under $1k. The cost of what it was vs what they are now is the only complaint. It would be nice to have 1 more HDMI port, and to have all ports on the bottom of the set, but that is OK.  Hi Def on comcast looks incredible. I don't have blu-ray, only an upconvert dvd. So, my only hi-def experience is through comcast Cable.  Standard Definition is OK too. It is a little blurry but as you sit farther from the set, you don't notice the blur.  Overall, It does not dissapoint. The sound is OK. If I had to do it all over again, I maybe would have gotten the next size up, but that is it. The clarity, the performance, the looks, its all great.  I highly recommend getting this set. I am more of an audio person, and I think this performs. Definately buy it if you find one used.

Reviews.Title: Fine deal... with a caveat
Reviews.Author: Norman F. Bohrer
Reviews.Content: This 47" refurbed Samsung 120Hz rates highest on all but one count. This one count is in the units frame design. The plastic frame surrounding the LCD screen is VERY suseptible to mars and scrapes. This refurbed unit showed this flaw clearly. My attempts to clean them  -without using harsh chemicals-  was almost useless. Revealing that the plastic is difficult to clean up with just mild soap and water.  In its design, it would have been better if a much thinner metal frame was used, so a mild solvent could be used for any cleaning.

Reviews.Title: Remarkable HDTV
Reviews.Author: N. Allen "Nick"
Reviews.Content: I absolutely love this HDTV.  I constantly get compliments from people about the amazing picture quality of this television.  I'm now looking for a smaller bedroom television and will definitely be sticking with a quality Samsung product such as this.

Reviews.Title: Great picture
Reviews.Author: John S. Dean "John"
Reviews.Content: This TV replaced a 42" insignia LCD.  There is no comparison, although I only paid $100 more for this than I paid for the Insignia less than 2 years ago.I hadn't planned on replacing my TV, since I was not dissatisfied with my old one, but the whole time I was beta testing Windows 7 on my media center, I could not use the HDMI out.  So I took the chance on the problem being with an older TV rather than my newer computer, and it paid off.  I got to use HDMI again.The picture is crisp, very little artifacts.  Sports, movies, everything looks good.  I spent the last couple days jumping randomly through my movie collection checking things out at 1080P again, and love the results.  So bright, so crisp, all without having to be in torch mode.My Xbox Elite is out for repair, so I went and bought a Sony PS3 and some games to try it out with, and games are outstanding.For a completely unplanned, spur of the moment purchase, I am very happy with this unit.  I had narrowed myself down to four different brands, a Sony, a LG, another Insignia ,and this.  When I went to the local brick and mortar, they had all of the nearby, and I was able to direct compare them all with the same source running, and this one, while more expensive than the others I was looking at, more than made up for the minor price difference by having such a noticeably better picture.And the fact that the remote is in the database for my Harmony One remote didn't hurt either - discrete codes for pretty much everything there is on the TV.Very happy in every respect with this TV.

Reviews.Title: Samsung HDTV
Reviews.Author: Renee M. Canfield
Reviews.Content: This tv is great.  We are very pleased with the quality of it.  We got a great price because it was open box and it is brand new.  We love it!

Reviews.Title: Excellent TV
Reviews.Author: Jay Kent
Reviews.Content: The price was lower than most stores advertised price and the clarity of this TV is unmatched.  I made the correct choice-no doubt about it.

Reviews.Title: awesome
Reviews.Author: reader "scott"
Reviews.Content: great product, great value.  get a blue ray player to really make full use of its capabilitites.

Reviews.Title: Samsung is High Quality
Reviews.Author: R. Gallese "RyanG34"
Reviews.Content: The reason I bought the A630 over the A650 was due to the Reflective Screen the 650 has. I didnt want to have any glare. The 650 won many awards on CNET.com which I trust. This TV is extremely clear and looks great too.I figured I would pay an extra 300-400 more $$ and buy a TV that would last me a while compared to a cheaper $800-900 off brand.Love the TV and it was shipped with the box in great condition and on time. Excellent experience overall.

Reviews.Title: FIne looking machine
Reviews.Author: Zachary D. Krohn
Reviews.Content: Before I bought this TV I looked and researched LCD TV's.  I checked out CNET.com, consumerreports.com, and then went into several stores like Best Buy to become familiar with the product.  Samsung has come a long way over the years and when I found out Samsung makes Sony's panel and that Sony was way overpriced it was an obvious choice.  Samsung beats out Sony not only in picture, but the aesthetics of the system.  The only down side I see is the 10W speakers, but honestly if you are going to buy a tv this big you are more than likely going to have a home theater system so that stat is obsolete.  I can't emphasize enough the importance of the matte finish on the screen.  This is the 630, the 650 has the high gloss screen.  If you have windows or lighting fixtures that will glare off the TV get the matte finish, when you bring it home you won't even know the difference.  THis is an awesome TV, the picture quality and options on this system are nice, but if you don't take my word for it check out CNET.com, they give you a video critique of the TV.  Other than that buying through Amazon I saved 500 dollars after talking with Best Buy about lowering their price.  ENJOY.

Reviews.Title: Awesome Television
Reviews.Author: J. Lido
Reviews.Content: Have had this television for about a month and I am enjoying it very much.  I did a lot of research to decide whether I wanted an LCD or a Plasma.  Since my living room receives a lot of light I decided to go with the LCD.  I also decided to go with the 630 instead of the 650 because of the matte screen.
